Hi, I am James Barthelman, the special education teacher in Newhalen. My wife, Stephanie, and our daughter, Josey, moved to the district two years ago. Previously we taught for 13 years in LKSD, up the coast.‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
Bush Alaska has a stranglehold on us. It won‚Äôt let go. We enjoy the simple pace. The quirks. Everywhere we have taught, everyone has been really helpful, knowledgeable, and good to us. Newhalen and LPSD are no exception. We love the student first approach. We love the progressive nature of the district. It is a top-notch bush school district. ‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
If I was talking to myself, back in 2005, I would make sure that kid took steams, ate everything at feasts, went hunting and fishing with locals, attended all the events and laughed a lot. First year teachers are always solid in the classroom. They wouldn‚Äôt be hired if they weren‚Äôt. Sometimes they get too caught up with their first year teaching and don‚Äôt get out enough. Connect with your new home and have fun!‚Å£‚Å£

@ Newhalen, Alaska

We also had local artist Beth Hill stop in to do an art project with the students, and Akila Osakwe did a presentation on drug awareness and prevention.

Ms. Hannah Ward!‚Å£
‚Å£
I am a 2013 graduate of Chignik Lake School. I served as a long-term substitute, a tutor, and completed my student teaching in this district.‚Å£
I am currently in my second year at Pilot Point as the elementary and head teacher.‚Å£
‚Å£
I planned on working in LPSD ever since I decided to go into education. My family had been in different locales in Alaska and I knew that LPSD was the best fit for me. The relationships that are developed among our school staffs are the kind that last well beyond work. Teachers working in small communities are able to reach out to others across the district for help and support. The administration works hard to make opportunities happen for staff so that not only are professional needs met but they also help teachers be successful community members. They realize that teachers have personal lives. Being a teacher in bush Alaska can be difficult, but our district assists in tackling the problems that we face so we can focus on the reason we're really here. ‚Å£

‚ÄúI have been working with LPSD since 2017. I got my Master's Degree in 2019 through an internship program with a district principal and UAS. I have supported district programs focusing on student success and involvement. ‚Å£

Why I Stay with LPSD - I stay with LPSD for the trusting freedom, continuous support, and unique experiences I have here. ‚Å£
Words of advice - In any new position, there is a learning curve.
